SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NEED OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON COMPLETING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences or prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces in the questions. If there is not enough space to answer the question, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneers' Diets: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A MODEL OF ORIENTATION TO THE PIONEER HISTORY OF SASKATCHEWAN

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences and some may be impossible for you to answer, so do not worry about answering all the questions. If there is not enough space to answer a question, please give details, or describe particular events, if they may help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and who have personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Tales: What I Did," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Canadian Pioneers' Experiences will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Collection at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

2. Your address: MOUNT RIDGE, KANSAS

3. Date: August 24th, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to say how long you have been in Saskatchewan. If you came by train, say so.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Family was looking for a future for his family.

They peoples that had heard of the possibilities in Saskatchewan.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

The Wilsons were very pleased to have me join them.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

We traveled together in a group of four.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We traveled by train from Chicago to Kansas City, then by horse-drawn wagon to our destination.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, mishaps or other experiences.

We met many interesting people along the way, including friendly Indians who helped us.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at the Wilson farm until we found a permanent home.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled on the farm of Mr. Bartel, who had arrived here the year before.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We lived on the farm of Mr. Bartel for two years, then moved to the farm of Mr. Wilson.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

We worked on the farm until the 1919 crop was harvested.
